data.title: Ayn Rand's Works, The Atlas Society
data.meta_description: Both as a thinker and as an artist, Ayn Rand swam against the tide. As a philosopher, she was an uncompromising champion of reason....
data.text:
Both as a thinker and as an artist, Ayn Rand swam against the tide. As a philosopher, she was an uncompromising champion of reason, individualism and pure capitalism. As a novelist, she was an impassioned Romantic. In both capacities, she was startling, original, unprecedented. And in both roles she obtained a worldwide audience for her philosophy of Objectivism.

The goal of her writing, she said, was not to capture a "slice of life," but to project her moral vision of man "as he might and ought to be."

And so the protagonists of her bestsellers (We the Living, Anthem, The Fountainhead, and Atlas Shrugged ) are heroic, Promethean individualistsâembattled titans in a world of envious Lilliputians.

And rejecting the notion that a "serious" novel had to be dull, she dramatized her philosophical themes in intricate plots loaded with color, romance, adventure and grandeur.

â

"In a certain sense, every novelist is a philosopher, because one cannot present a picture of human existence without a philosophical framework." Â Ayn Rand, 1960

In addition to penning best-selling novels, Rand wrote serious works on philosophy and cultural and political analysis and criticism. Some of these articles and essays appeared in magazines such as Cosmopolitan, the New York Times Magazine, and Human Events.

In 1962 she and Nathaniel Branden began publishing The Objectivist Newsletter, which was renamed The Objectivist in 1966. That same year the newsletter serialized Rand's "Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology." Her highly influential book Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal was published Â in 1966, and included chapters by economists Alan Greenspan and Robert Hessen, and Rand's former associate Nathaniel Branden. In 1971 the newsletter was renamed The Ayn Rand Letter. Several books with material culled from her newsletter articles were published posthumously.

Explore the links below to learn more about this fascinating author's fiction and non-fiction work.

AYN RAND'S NOVELS

Atlas Shrugged (1957) This is Ayn Randâs masterwork â her monumental story of the man who swore he would stop the motor of the world, and did. It is the novel in which Rand first presented and dramatized her radical morality of rational self-interest â and which has launched a philosophical revolution.

The Fountainhead (1943) The powerful novel that made Ayn Rand famous: the story of a rebellious individualist, architect Howard Roark â and his battle to live and work by his own standards.

Anthem (1938) A beautifully written and inspiring novelette of a man who, in a totally collectivist future, rediscovers his own sense of selfhood.

We the Living (1936) The dramatic story of one young womanâs struggle for freedom during Russian Revolution, as she is torn between two men: the aristocrat she loves, and the dangerous communist who loves her.

AYN RAND'S SHORT STORIES

The Husband I Bought (1926)

Good Copy (c.a. 1927)

Escort (1929)

Her Second Career (1929)

These early short stories were not intended for publication, but were written while Ayn Rand was still learning her literary craft and gaining familiarity with the English language. They have considerable charm, however, and contain the seeds of ideas and values that would characterize her mature work. These stories and others are anthologized in The Early Ayn Rand.

"The Simplest Thing in the World" (1940). This short story, which shows how an artistâs values affect his creative processes, appears in Ayn Randâs nonfiction work, The Romantic Manifesto: A Philosophy of Literature.

"Red Pawn" (c. 1931-32). This short story, set in a Soviet prison camp for political dissidents, dramatizes enduring themes of individualism and love.

Read: Â A Glimpse of the Early Ayn Rand.

AYN RAND'S PLAYS

Night of January 16th (1936) This exciting courtroom melodrama ran successfully on Broadway, and is a staple of the amateur stage. A truly unique feature of this play is that the jury is chosen from the audienceâand how they decide the trial is determined by their philosophies.

Ideal (1934) The theme of this bitter play centers on peopleâs willingness to betray their highest values. It appears in the anthology of Randâs work titled The Early Ayn Rand.

Unconquered (1938) Ayn Rand adapted this play from her novel, We the Living. Though it ran on Broadway briefly, it was not successful. It has not yet been published

Think Twice (1939) A clever murder mystery, and the first of Randâs mature works, this play appears in the collection The Early Ayn Rand.

AYN RAND'S NON-FICTION BOOKS

For the New Intellectual (1961)

The Virtue of Selfishness (1964)

Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal (1967)

The Romantic Manifesto (1970)

The New Left: The Anti-Industrial Revolution (1971) [Republished as Return of the Primitive: The Anti-Industrial Revolution (1999), with additional essays by Peter Schwartz.]

Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology (1979)

NON-FICTION PUBLISHED POSTHUMOUSLY

Philosophy: Who Needs It (1982)

The Voice of Reason (1988)

The Ayn Rand Column (1991)

The Letters of Ayn Rand (1995)

Ayn Randâs Marginalia (1995)

Journals of Ayn Rand (1997)

Russian Writings on Hollywood (1999)

The Ayn Rand Reader (1999)
